history.content: I feel 61B isn't exactly sufficient for doing leetcode/interview style questions. Those questions require more knowledge like Dynamic Programming and more complex algorithms than you've seen in 61B. You can go through some of the materials for 170 to learn this.

children.subject:
I never took CS170, but am going through Hackerrank interview questions.

The problems definitely would be easier if I had taken CS170 or other advanced algorithm courses, but I'm finding just following some algorithm solving principles outlined in CTCI have been working well enough for me.

Alternatively, if this doesn't work, reading up on specific problem domains (dynamic programming, greedy algorithms etc.) on the internet give you enough grounding to solve the problems using the technique outlined above.

history.content: I'm practicing CTCI right now and I'm already struggling on the first few DS questions. I've took 61b last semester but I feel like there's something I'm missing when I try out harder interview questions. I feel confident in knowing what the data structures are and how/when to use them, but for some reason when I'm actually doing problems I just don't know how to do them, even after a lot of time spent on my whiteboard trying to figure things out. ​ Is there a problem methodology I'm simply missing, or is the key really just churning out problem after problem? And the secret really is just practice, then is it okay to look at the solutions every once in a while with an emphasis and understanding why the solutions are what they are?
history.subject: Getting good at leetcode/interview questions: just a matter of practice or am I missing something?
